moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. f4 g6 4. Nf3 Bg7: Black seeks to gain a rook after 8. Rxf3 Nd4, 9.  R moves Nxc2
moves.8. Rxf3 Nd4 9. Bb5+: Black's best move here may be 9...Nxb5, as after 10. Nxb5 Nf6 Black has an edge in position and development with forces even. However, Black persists in his plan to grab a Rook.
moves.9... Kf8 10. Rf1 Nxc2 11. Qd1 Nxa1 12. b: Black can stay ahead with either 12... Nxb3 o 12... Bxc3.
moves.12... Nf6: The N gets in the game, but Black can no longer castle and the Black King is cramped.
moves.13. Bb2 Nxe4: Opening the a1-h8 diagonal is a two edged sword...
moves.14. Qxa1: Aligning the Q and B on the long diagonal.
moves.15. Nd5: Opening the diagonal and threatening a strong counter-attack. If 15...Bxb2 16. Qxb2, white closes the material gap by picking up the N (as 16...Nxf1, 17. Qxh8++ is ruinous. That is probably Black's best move here as it leaves him a two pawn advantage and time to mobilize. But Black plays for the Rook. 15...d5 or 15...f6 are also acceptable but not as strong.
moves.15... Nxf1: ?? Not regarding the consequences of 16. BxB+
moves.16. Bxg7+: The beginning of the end for Black as White now regains material and makes serious threats.
moves.17. Bxh8:
Now what does Black do? 
17...Qf8 18. Nxe7 Qxe7 19. Qg7++
17. Kf8 Qg7++
17. e5 or f6 Nxf6 leads to several lines, none of which favor Black
moves.17... Ne3:
?? Perhaps Black chose suicide after realizing his dilemma.
Or perhaps he merely overlooked the coup de grace.

opening: Sicilian (B23), Grand Prix attack, Schofman variation
